Message.Title: Use the cash to buy back shares and invest in the company
Message.Msg: Strategic plan grow the company. Buy back shares, which appear to be going down on the news, and invest some in developing products. The only bad thing I see is the timing of the announcement of the "review". If Alibaba paid off tomorrow then it would be fine. But, for those holding shares the news is not so good if the pps keeps dropping between now and the Alibaba payment. Of course, in the long run.....the buying back shares should (but may not) ultimately increase the value of shares.

Topic.Title: Smart move for Marissa is not a smart move for yahoo..

Message.Msg: Share buyback has always proven to be a nonproductive use of money. Those companies which tend to do it are basically saying that they have no more ideas, no more growth. I give up. Here, take the money. We cannot figure out a use for it. Rather than just crawl along year after year, Yahoo now has the ability to really expand their business. Sure it may be risky. But the alternative would be to see the pps trade in the same channel for years to come.

Message.Title: Surprised?
Message.Msg: A few months ago, I posted that there was no way that YHOO was going to give shareholders that money. I was vilified for it. Oh, the longs here were creaming themselves thinking about receiving a big, fat dividend payout that was soon to be coming their way. I was laughing at the naivete. You think that's YOUR money? heheh. How foolish. There was no way that those controlling YHOO were going to get billions of dollars and give it to little shareholders like you rather than roll the dice on recapturing YHOO's glory days. Why wouldn't the new CEO swing for the fences? She has no downside. Like a hedge fund manager playing with other people's money. Heads she becomes a superstar "the woman who saved Yahoo", tails she's Carly Fiorina. No matter what she is filthy rich. I see a lot of negativity regarding what YHOO might do with the money, but I think that is premature. Had they not invested in Alibaba, the stock would be almost worthless. So....you never know. The odds are they will waste the money. True. That's what history has shown us. But every now and then, it does work out for the better. Either way, the RISK in Yahoo just went up dramatically. Invest accordingly.

Message.Title: Alibaba Group's Jan-March net profit soars-SEC filing
Message.Msg: Aug 10 (Reuters) - Alibaba Group, China's largest e-commerce company, posted a 64.2 percent rise in revenue in the January-March quarter and its net profit jumped more than sixfold to $220.5 million, according to a U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission filing. The filing from Yahoo Inc, which owns 40 percent of Alibaba, is the first to show how strongly one of China's most closely followed Internet companies performed during the period.

Topic.Title: Alibaba Group's Jan-March net profit soars-SEC filing

Message.Msg: For the six months that ended March 31, Alibaba's revenue rose 76.7 percent to $1.83 billion, while net profit rose 638.9 percent to $457.4 million. The filing shows Alibaba's income from operations rising to $490 million in the same period from $73.2 million a year ago, a jump of about 569 percent.

Topic.Title: Marissa is 200% correct.

Message.Msg: Well, she MAY be correct, but that really depends on what she uses the money for. My problem with her suggestion that she may not be issuing a dividend or even buy back stock is the timing of it. There was no reason for her to say anything right now. She already announced on Day 1 of her tenure that she would be reviewing YAHOO's business and policies for the first few months, so there was no reason to reiterate that now and combine it with a statement that the potential dividend/buyback plan may be abandoned. The way to do that would be to make the decision in private and then announce that change in policy at the same time that she announces what exactly she proposes to do with the money. The way she chose to do it, the inevitable result was a substantial reduction in the price of YHOO stock due to massive sales by disgruntled, nervous and fed-up shareholders. I can't think of any reason for her recent announcement other than a deliberate attempt to deflate the price of YHOO shares, so that certain people will benefit -- people like Loeb (or even herself), for instance, who probably wouldn't mind the chance to buy YHOO on the cheap one or two more times. However, I think that is contrary to the duties she owes to other shareholders, particularly those who may need to sell their YHOO shares now for economic or emergency reasons. One other problem I have with this is that it's one more example of how this company is looking more and more like a chicken running around with its head cut off. One day, we have dividends and buybacks, the next day we have acquisitions instead. One day we're a media company, the next day we're a tech company. One day we're compacting the company, the next day we're expanding. One day, we're cutting payroll, the next day we're going to add tons of new high-cost engineers. No wonder the market remains leary of this stock.

Message.Title: the history of tech acquisitions have been a history of big blowups - writedowns...
Message.Msg: lets not just pick on Marissa, but yahoo shareholders need a wake up call. In the history of tech acquisitions, there is probably way more overspending/writeoffs/failures on an epic level (HP, AOL,EDS, MSFT...) than positive outcomes. That is why institutionals are dumping shares today, the odds of a good outcome is low, and this is a risk/reward game. Instead of investors getting a healthy payout so they can decide on their own how to invest the proceeds, Marissa believes she can do it for them by spending when Nasdaq valuations are at its highest levels... yeah, that will make any investor nervous as hell. Marissa is gambling, but she is guaranteed $70 million so what does she care if her acquisitions flop? even she gets lucky and that 1% chance of success and she hits lotto, her career is minted and she can have any other CEO tech job later on. I would do the same if I were Marissa, take the chances because upside only for CEO, no downside...for shareholders, different story, u are screwed.

Message.Title: Mayer to replace almost the entire Yahoo executive team, from its CFO Tim Morse on down
Message.Msg: Mayer is reaching out to a number of execs outside the company, including Twitter exec Katie Stanton, as well as perusing at a series of start-ups to bring new people into the company. She has made two hires of mid-level execs from Google — both of whom have been described to me as longtime Mayer loyalists. But she has still to pull in a big name or deeply experienced exec to her team. We’ll be watching for that, as well as who’s next to go in this game of “10 Little Yahoos.” Sources at the company said that they expect Mayer to replace almost the entire current executive team, from its CFO Tim Morse on down. AllThingsD
